job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Time off and schedule goes based on whole hospital seniority not just your floor. You can have someone who’s never worked in your department before come in and get best hours and whatever days they want off because they worked 20 years in another unit and you’re teaching them. Pay is better now, but the extra 8 hour shifts every 2 weeks on top of your 6 12’s makes it feel like you’re there all the time. Get rid of the extra 8 SBUH!
cons: Extra 8 hr shift, shafted with seniority, never get the days you want off

Benefits 
Room for movement within the facility
Education
My unit had a handful of very helpful PAs and RNs but let me tell you that’s not the norm here.
cons:
Short staffed. Attitudes from older nurses. Favoritism with vacation picks, assignments and scheduling. Haven’t been able to take a personal day in over a year.  Management doesn’t care about you.  Retirement system sucks unless you’ve worked for the state prior to 2012
Extremely toxic environment throughout the hospital. No precepting pay or charge nurse pay as a staff nurse with extra responsibility. Always floating to other units when our unit is short.  Staff is burnt out. Oh and you pay to park in the only lot we are allowed to park in.

job_title: Manager in Stony Brook, NY

review_title: Please help-I don't want to leave..I just need to advance in position and salary...
job_title: Clerk I  in Stony Brook, NY
pros: One feels part of a very diverse community. Where you can be proud of the many accomplishments. Growth is phenomonal, and as a large family we strive always to give our very best. Controversy and accomadation are a constant surrounding the atmosphere- where all walks of life contribute to each facility. The results- a university and medical center to be proud. Our reputation most certainly has left  it's mark on the map of recognition.
cons: It is hard to move around- I personally have met with this diservice. I returned to school and met the requirements for a BA. ,unfortunately-I have yet to find an opportunity to utilize my degree, without having to leave the institution. I have 4 years to retirement and starting at entry level eslewhere seems counter productive.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Coram, NY
pros: pension, union, flexible work schedule
cons: decreased pay, minimal support from management

job_title: Nursing Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: They say good benefits but you never get to use the benefits unless your old and have health problems. Employees pay for a thousand things and never get anything back. Pay Union and the union never help when you have a problem.
cons: The pay is so low. The annual rate is good but when you see your check it's a misery. Working for the state is really not the best job in the world. As a nursing assistant I was being abuse. 25 patients and no nurses ever help. Management does whatever they want since they have a union and can't get fired like that. My experience as an employee and as a patient was HORRIBLE. Will never recomend this place to anybody. Students with no experience are doing the work a doctor should do while the doctor just relax. Same with nurses the only difference is that nurses have nursing assistant to do everything for them.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Stony Brook, NY
pros: I love being a CNA. I lived in town. Good benefits, Nyship to be exact. Union state job Csea. Fortunate to leave with a 10 year pension. Great co-workers. I enjoyed working side by side with nurse’s getting through the shift.
cons: Understaffed, poor management and nurse’s don’t help with patient care (even if it’s their assigned patient). Weekends I ended up with 15 patients on a 30 bed floor for several years nothing changed. Vitals x2, accu-checks x2, I&O’s and of course call bells  which nurse’s don’t answer. Shift 3-11pm. Also nurse’s don’t help even if theres only one CNA on the floor.  Imagine this was second best staffed shift. Nights was always 1 cna on the floor.  Nurse overall attitude is not my patient not my problem. Everyone for themselves.

review_title: Good place to learn, but terrible to stay after a short while.
job_title: ICU RN in Middle Island, NY
pros: Teaching facility where you can get a good foundation on the latest evidence based practice as a RN. Educators are good here.
cons: Terrible staffing ratios, and pay. RN's are paid about $10,000 more at other surrounding hospitals on Long Island. They will continue to proclaim that their pension is the most attractive aspect but you'll actually get more for retirement if you saved some of the extra money you'd be making at other hospitals. Most managers don't really care about concerns or wellbeing of their employees. Institution is very much into ensuring that  everything looks like its working as opposed to it actually working. Aesthetics is where a lot of this hospitals budget goes.

review_title: Stony Brook is the home of the best ideas in medicine.  All ideas, no action.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY
pros:
Great pension, decent overall benefits package, and comprehensive, affordable health care.
Very good staffing ratios, when compared to similar hospitals on Long Island.  Given excellent resources (clinicians, educators, CNS) to perform your duties.
Union protection.
cons: Sometimes difficult to get time off (depending where you work.)  Union rules make it almost impossible to get rid of really bad employees.   You have to pay for parking!

review_title: Stony Brook Medicine amazing benefits and  all the overtime
job_title: CT Technologist in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Excessive overtime available throughout every shifts. Friendly environment. Awesome teamwork. The benefits is the biggest perk. Most importantly, it gives a sense of pride to work for an reputable hospital.
cons: Tuition reimbursement is not pleasing especially only covering one class per semester and only through SUNY schools.  Favoritism for certain employees for which prevents you to move up the ladder

job_title: Statistics Teacher in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Students are great, loved working with the kids. the manager was great. learned many thing from him.I have had the opportunity to learn from some of the most talented, dedicated, generous educators imaginable. Within my time with SBMS, I have been invited to participate in academic and literacy trainings that have significantly impacted my assigned students. Stony Brook Medical School has also provided me with the opportunity to work with a variety of students in terms of age, grade, and disability levels. It was great experience.
cons: There was not enough time to teach and not enough pay. The statistics subject is not emphasized in medical school.

job_title: Senior Lab Worker in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Job security!  Once you're in...YOU"RE IN!!!
cons: Like in any other facility that is open 24 hours a day ~  365 days a year....you have to work holidays and weekends.

review_title: Excellent Hospital and Place To Work
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Stony Brook, NY
pros: I have always wanted to work at Stony Brook since I was a cancer patient there and felt I was provided with exceptional care and I liked how they are a teaching hospital which means they are innovative with their diagnoses and treatment plans. As an employee, I feel that I am treated great respect by my coworkers and supervisors. I am happy with my salary for the work that I do and overall have a very pleasant work environment.
cons: Not as much room for growth as I would have hoped for

review_title: Was rewarding but slow at times. The research being done if top of the line though.
job_title: Research Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: There was a good environment for budding minds and those who wanted to get things done.
cons: There were also those who just did the bare minimum and did not contribute much to the research goals or the weekly quota.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: I worked in the hospital side and the academic side. I learned a lot and met a lot of wonderful people during my time at Stony Brook University Medical Center. It's a great place to work.
cons: For the new employee, entering the building from the HSC parking garage and finding your way to your office is certainly annoying. Be sure to give yourself an extra 10 minutes to make it to your office on time.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Teaching hospital, close to home,easily accessible low cost employee parking
cons: Poor employees mortale,  No incentive to retain employment Very underpaid staff, poor vacation packages, Overworked staff.

job_title: PICU Attending in Stony Brook, NY

cons: there is a Nursing shortage in pediatrics and lack of responsibility for who with fix it to provide safe and effective care.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Great benefits, pension and flexibility with shift work. Fantastic resources, ability to learn and advance.
cons: very top heavy with regards to nursing management. Nursing Management, stuck in the past with regards to employee satisfaction. No support of nursing staff from management. Punitive environment.

review_title: It pays well, with a price.
job_title: EMT-B in Stony Brook, NY
pros: With 12 hour shifts you only work 7 out of 14 days in a pay period. Salary is decent for an EMT. You are exposed to and learn a lot outside of your scope of practice. Plenty of education opportunity.
cons: Little room for advancement, no regular days off, consistently looked down on and degraded as an "ambulance driver" by supervision.

job_title: Staff RN in Stony Brook, NY
pros:
Great benefits - especially the NYS Pension, excellent health insurance
Decent staffing ratios
cons:
Much lower pay than other local hospitals ($10-20K/yr.)
The hospital is run very inefficiently.  Way too much dead weight at the top.
Every outside administrator with a history of success in another organization gets crushed by "The Stony Brook Way."  Then, nothing changes!

review_title: Standard office work, laid back environment
job_title: Office Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Standard office work. Filing, data entry, light labor (organizing materials in the supply closet), copying and faxing, mailing, etc. Very flexible with schedule considering this was a student position. Office dress code was fairly casual.
cons: None really. I worked at the communications office which is in a separate location from the actual medical center, so I had to commute from campus (luckily, I have a car)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Selden, NY
pros: This is a very progressive hospital which is aiming to implement discoveries and ideas from the university into application at the hospital. This will become more evident when the MART building is completed.
cons: There is a challenge to remain connected with the other members of the institution as it is such a big organization

job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Good work environment, potential for advancement.  The hospital is the only trauma one center in the region so you will get to see the most complicated of cases. Starbucks in the lobby!
cons: Cafeteria tends to be expensive, parking is paid. Some disgruntled nurses work here, but thankfully not as many. Hiring tends to lean on the nepotism side.

job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Patchogue, NY
pros: Good for new grads to get  the experience.  Every other job will be than this one when you leave.
cons: The PAY is the lowest in long island.  Resp therapist , RN's, Xray, will make $10K to $20K working elsewhere.  The work loads are HEAVY.  The unions SUCK.  You pay to park your car.  Prejudicial merit raises given to office pets.  ALBANY screws with your benefits often.

review_title: RN- Not what it used to be
job_title: Registered Nurse in Stony Brook, NY

review_title: Tertiary hospital setting, serving lots of people
